title: Method for screening and treating patients at risk of medical disorders

events.title: Assigned to TRANSNEURONIX, INC.
description: ASSIGNMENT OF ASSIGNORS INTEREST (SEE DOCUMENT FOR DETAILS).
Assignors: MAUDE-GRIFFIN, ROLAND, JENKINS, DAVID A.

classifications.description: ICT specially adapted for medical diagnosis, medical simulation or medical data mining; ICT specially adapted for detecting, monitoring or modelling epidemics or pandemics for simulation or modelling of medical disorders

ICT specially adapted for therapies or health-improving plans, e.g. for handling prescriptions, for steering therapy or for monitoring patient compliance relating to drugs or medications, e.g. for ensuring correct administration to patients
ICT specially adapted for therapies or health-improving plans, e.g. for handling prescriptions, for steering therapy or for monitoring patient compliance relating to nutrition control, e.g. diets

ICT specially adapted for therapies or health-improving plans, e.g. for handling prescriptions, for steering therapy or for monitoring patient compliance relating to mental therapies, e.g. psychological therapy or autogenous training

ICT specially adapted for medical diagnosis, medical simulation or medical data mining; ICT specially adapted for detecting, monitoring or modelling epidemics or pandemics for mining of medical data, e.g. analysing previous cases of other patients

abstract: Method for screening patients to predict which patients at risk of a medical disorder, such as morbid obesity, gastrointestinal problems, or gastroesophageal problems, will be responders, and conversely, which patients will not, to achieve a favorable outcome from therapy for that disorder. This method supports an intervention strategy for patients having weight or gastrointestinal problems that will cut health costs. It enables patients and care-givers alike to more efficiently use their time, efforts and resources by enabling an early selection of an appropriate treatment modality for a given patient. Its application also extends to other implantable medical devices and therapies using them.
claims:
1. A method for predicting the weight loss outcome of the application of therapy to a patient for treating an eating, gastrointestinal, or gastroesophageal disorder, comprising: 
a) obtaining items of information from a patient at risk of one of an eating, gastro-intestinal, and gastroesophageal disorder, each item of information relating to a preselected patient variable;  b) predicting a weight loss outcome for the patient from the obtained information for the patient using an aggregated weight loss predictor developed from i) observed similar types of information and corresponding weight loss information obtained from an actual population of patients who previously received a similar therapy to that proposed for the patient, or ii) information generated from a simulated population of patients by resampling the observed actual population information to produce pseudo-replicates.
2. The method of claim 1, where the therapy is applied through the use of an implantable pulse generator.
3. The method of claim 1, where the therapy is application of a banding type device.
4. The method of claim 1, where the therapy is a bariatric type surgery.
5. The method of claim 1, where the therapy is a non-surgical behavioral modification.
6. The method of claim 2, where the therapy is a pharmaceutical or medicinal therapy.

7. The method of claim 1, wherein predicting the weight loss outcome comprises processing the items of information using an aggregated classification and regression tree model formed using a committee or ensemble method combining multiple predictors trained in perturbed versions of the observed items of information.
8. The method of claim 7, wherein the committee or ensemble method is selected from one of a boosting algorithm, a bagging algorithm, or an arcing algorithm.

9. The method of claim 7, further comprising training the aggregated classification and regression tree model by preprocessing i) historical data comprising actual patient information of patients who previously received similar therapy to that proposed for the patient, and ii) the corresponding weight loss outcomes those patients to learn how to predict weight loss outcomes.

10. The method of claim 9, wherein the preprocessing comprises: 
reducing the quantity of the historical patient information and corresponding patient weight loss outcomes;  reducing the number of variables contained in the historical patient information and corresponding patient weight loss outcomes using classification and regression trees;  transforming the values of the historical patient information and corresponding patient weight loss outcomes;  applying the ensemble or committee method selected from a boosting algorithm or a bagging algorithm to the extracted features; and  generating the classification and regression tree model to predict a weight loss outcome from the boosted or bagged, extracted features.

11. The method of claim 9, further comprising testing the trained aggregated classification and regression tree model through a cross-validating procedure that comprises the steps of: 
1) randomly dividing the observed sample into a training set and a hold out test set;  2) repeatedly training the predictive model in perturbed versions of the randomly selected training set by a committee or ensemble method selected from the group consisting of a boosting algorithm and a bagging algorithm;  3) applying each of the resulting predictors to the hold-out test set, and aggregating predictions by averaging and majority voting for use in screening test set subjects to determine their suitability for treatment;  4) repeating steps 1), 2) and 3) at least once; and  5) averaging at least one outcome statistic of interest for selected and rejected test set subjects across replications, and  6) using results of step 5) to assess the usefulness of the predictive screening model for improving expected treatment outcomes.

12. The method of claim 9, wherein predicting the weight loss outcome comprises processing the items of information using an aggregated classification and regression tree model formed using an ensemble or committee algorithm including a combination of many distinct trees, each model estimated in a sequence of systematically and/or randomly perturbed version of the original sample, and wherein a screening decision for a patient is then based on a combination of average predicted weight loss across ensemble or committee trees and/or a majority vote criterion comprising whether a majority of the ensemble or committee trees predict weight loss above a predetermined threshold level.
13. The method of claim 1, wherein the items of information include psychometric data.
14. The method of claim 13, wherein the psychometric data include answers by the patient to questions asked in a RAND Short Form 36 (SF-36) health survey.

15. The method of claim 1, wherein the items of information obtained from a patient are selected from at least one of symptoms, demographics, tests of psychological well being, family history, eating habits, diet, exercise, and other attempted weight loss therapies.
16. The method of claim 1, wherein the information comprises anthropometric data.
17. The method of claim 1, wherein the information comprises biomarker data.
18. The method of claim 1, wherein the information includes body mass index.

19. The method of claim 1, wherein the weight loss variable data includes RAND scores calculated for answers made by the patient to questions asked in a RAND Short Form 36 (SF-36) health survey (version 1.0), and anthropometric data of the patient including at least one of the patient's height, weight, sex, and age.

20. The method of claim 1, wherein the predicting comprises comparing the weight loss variable data to similar data gathered from an actual or simulated patient population for which results to an obesity therapy have been precollected or precalculated, respectively, effective to permit a classification of the patient in terms of a probable outcome to proposed similar therapy to the obesity therapy.
21. The method of claim 20, wherein the processing and the comparing are at least partially performed by a computer.
22. The method of claim 20, further comprising rendering a decision as to whether or not to treat the patient's disorder with the similar therapy based on the classification of the patient.
23. The method of claim 1, wherein the disorder treated is selected from obesity, metabolic syndrome, or their related comorbidities.

24. The method of claim 23, wherein the treated disorder comprises at least one of the related comorbidities selected from high blood pressure, hypertension, high blood cholesterol, dyslipidemia, Type 2 diabetes, insulin resistance, glucose intolerance, hyperinsulinemia, coronary heart disease, angina pectoris, congestive heart failure, stroke, gallstones, cholesystitis, cholelithiasis, gastroeophageal reflux disease, gout, osteoarthritis, obstructive sleep apnea, sleep apnea complications related to pregnancy, cancer, menstrual irregularities, infertility, irregular ovulation, stress incontinence, uric acid nephrolithiasis, depression, eating disorders, distorted body image, or low self esteem.
25. The method of claim 1, wherein a) and b) are performed before, during, or after an animal clinical trial to demonstrate safety or efficacy of a medicinal therapy or medical device.

26. The method of claim 1, wherein the information comprises biomarker information selected from hormone information, peptide information, genomics information, body scan information, or any combination thereof.

27. The method of claim 1, wherein the information comprises biomarker information selected from ghrelin peptide information, blood glucose measurements, hemoglobin AIC information, or any combination thereof.

28. A method for treating a patient at risk of an eating disorder, a gastrointestinal disorder, or an esophageal disorder, comprising: 
a) obtaining items of patient information comprising i) psychometric data, ii) anthropometric data, and, optionally, iii) biomarker information;  b) processing the information into a comparable format;  c) comparing the information in the comparable format to similar information gathered from an actual or simulated population of patients for which treatment outcomes are known or computed, respectively;  d) rendering a decision as to whether or not to treat the patient's disorder with electrical stimulation of tissue of the patient; and  e) treating, when the decision rendered in d) is affirmative, such patient by electrical stimulation of tissue of the patient in a manner effective to alleviate the patient's disorder.
29. The method of claim 28, wherein the patient is at risk of an eating disorder selected from one of anorexia, bulimia, or obesity.
30. The method of claim 28, wherein the patient is at risk of a gastrointestinal disorder selected from one of gastroparesis, irritable bowel syndrome, gastric ulcers, or gastric motility.
31. The method of claim 28, wherein the patient is at risk of an esophageal disorder selected from one of esophagitis, hiatal hernia, or gastroesophageal reflux.

32. The method of claim 28, wherein such electrical stimulation is sourced internally to neuromuscular tissue of the patient from either an implantable device or sourced externally to neuromuscular tissue of the patient from a device external to the body.
33. The method of claim 28, wherein such electrical stimulation is sourced internally to tissue in the viscera of the patient via an implanted device.
34. The method of claim 28, wherein the processing and the comparing are at least partially performed by a computer.

35. The method of claim 28, wherein the items of information obtained from a patient are selected from at least one of symptoms, demographics, tests of psychological well being, family history, eating habits, diet, exercise, and other attempted therapies.
36. The method of claim 28, further comprising, after rendering and before treating, specifying the parameters of electrical stimulation to be utilized based on such processed information.

37. The method of claim 37, wherein the specified parameters are selected from at least one of amount of current, amount of voltage, number of utilized channels, number of utilized electrodes, location of electrodes, type of tissue to be stimulated, length of pulses or pulse trains, frequency of pulses, on-off times for stimulation, and sensor usage.

38. The method of claim 37, wherein the specified parameter includes at least the type of tissue to be stimulated, wherein the type of tissue is selected from at least one of brain tissue, gastrointestinal tissue, nerve tissue, or cardiac tissue.

39. The method of claim 28, wherein the electrical stimulation of tissue of the patient comprises installing electrodes at tissue selected from the viscera, lesser curve of stomach, greater curve of stomach, fundus of stomach, antrum of stomach, duodenum, esophagus, cardiac tissue, brain tissue, nerve tissue, the spinal cord, or combinations thereof.
40. The method of claim 28, where the tissue comprises the vagus nerve.
41. The method of claim 28, wherein the tissue comprises sympathetic nerve tissues.
42. The method of claim 28, where an implantable pulse generator is used to electrically stimulate neuro-muscular tissue or nerve tissue of the body.
43. The method of claim 42, wherein the tissue is selected from the stomach, the intestines, the brain, the vagus nerve, sympathetic nerves, or the spinal cord.

44. The method of claim 28, wherein the items of information include a patient's answers provided to questions of a lifestyle, quality of life, mental health, or mental well-being questionnaire comprising a RAND SF-36 form.

45. The method of claim 28, wherein items of information include biomarker information selected from hormone information, peptide information, genomics information, body scan information, or any combination thereof.

46. The method of claim 28, wherein the items of information include biomarker information selected from ghrelin peptide information, blood glucose measurements, hemoglobin AIC information, or any combination thereof.
47. The method of claim 28, wherein the items of information include biomarker information comprising results of a positron emission tomography brain scan.
48. The method of claim 28, wherein a), b), c), d), and e) are performed before, during, or after an animal clinical trial to demonstrate safety or efficacy of a medicinal therapy or medical device.

49. A method of screening or optimization of a patient in advance of a medical treatment, comprising: 
a) developing a predictive model for outcomes of patients who will receive the medical treatment as part of a therapy or treatment of a medical condition or disorder, comprising applying data mining techniques, and advanced regression tree analysis to build, train and test a predictive model for predicting the outcomes of patients receiving the therapy;  b) collecting data from a prospective patient for the same therapy;  c) using the predictive model to predict the possible outcome of the prospective patient for the therapy.

50. A method of claim 49, where such screening or optimization uses scoring from a lifestyle, quality of life, mental health or mental well-being questionnaire, for the purpose of determining, in advance, the efficacy of the therapy.
51. The method of claim 49, wherein medical treatment comprises the implantation of a medical device in the patient.
52. The method of claim 49, wherein medical treatment comprises applying a pharmaceutical regimen to the patient.
53. The method of claim 49, wherein medical treatment comprises applying a medicinal regimen to the patient.
54. The method of claim 49, wherein a), b), and c) are performed before, during, or after an animal clinical trial to demonstrate safety or efficacy of a medicinal therapy or medical device.

55. A method of screening or optimization of patients in advance of the application of an obesity therapy, comprising: 
a) developing a predictive model for outcomes of patients who will have the obesity therapy as part of a treatment for obesity and comorbidities thereof, comprising applying data mining techniques, and advanced regression tree analysis to build, train and test a predictive model for predicting the outcomes of patients receiving the therapy;  b) collecting data from a prospective patient for the same therapy;  c) using the predictive model to predict the possible outcome of the prospective patient for the therapy.

56. A method of claim 55, wherein the screening or optimization uses scoring from a lifestyle, quality of life, mental health or mental well-being questionnaire, for the purpose of determining, in advance, the efficacy of the therapy.
57. The method of claim 56, wherein the questionnaire contains between about 20 and about 60 individual indications for response.
58. The method of claim 57, wherein the questionnaire is the RAND SF-36 form.
59. The method of claim 55, wherein the obesity therapy comprises a surgical procedure.
60. The method of claim 55, wherein the obesity therapy comprises installing an implantable gastric stimulator in the patient.
61. The method of claim 55, wherein the obesity therapy comprises bariatric surgery.

62. The method of claim 61, wherein the obesity therapy further comprises treatment of at least one of the comorbidities selected from high blood pressure, hypertension, high blood cholesterol, dyslipidemia, Type 2 diabetes, insulin resistance, glucose intolerance, hyperinsulinemia, coronary heart disease, angina pectoris, congestive heart failure, stroke, gallstones, cholesystitis, cholelithiasis, gastroeophageal reflux disease, gout, osteoarthritis, obstructive sleep apnea, sleep apnea complications related to pregnancy, cancer, menstrual irregularities, infertility, irregular ovulation, stress incontinence, uric acid nephrolithiasis, depression, eating disorders, distorted body image, or low self esteem.
63. The method of claim 55, wherein the obesity therapy comprises a pharmaceutical regimen.
64. The method of claim 55, wherein the obesity therapy comprises a medicinal regimen.

65. The method of claim 55, wherein a), b), and c) are performed before, during, or after an animal clinical trial to demonstrate safety or efficacy of a surgical procedure, medicinal therapy, or medical device.
66. A method comprising using a Rand SF 36 questionnaire as a criterion to determine, partly or wholly, inclusion or exclusion of a candidate subject to a human clinical trial.
67. The method of claim 66, wherein said human clinical trial comprises overweight therapy, metabolic therapy, obesity therapy, or their respective comorbidities.

68. The method of claim 67, wherein the clinical trial comprises treatment of at least one of the comorbidities selected from high blood pressure, hypertension, high blood cholesterol, dyslipidemia, Type 2 diabetes, insulin resistance, glucose intolerance, hyperinsulinemia, coronary heart disease, angina pectoris, congestive heart failure, stroke, gallstones, cholesystitis, cholelithiasis, gastroeophageal reflux disease, gout, osteoarthritis, obstructive sleep apnea, sleep apnea complications related to pregnancy, cancer, menstrual irregularities, infertility, irregular ovulation, stress incontinence, uric acid nephrolithiasis, depression, eating disorders, distorted body image, or low self esteem.
